speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Tesla's first quarter twenty twenty two Q and A webcast. My name is Martin Vieka, VP of Investor Relations, and I'm joined today by Elon Musk, Zachary Kirkhorn and a number of other executives. Our Q1 results were announced at about three pm Central Time in the update that we published at the same link as this webcast. During this call, we will discuss our business outlook and make forward looking statements. These comments are based on our predictions and expectations as of today.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Actual events and results could differ materially due to a number of risks and uncertainties, including those mentioned in our most recent filings with the SEC. During the question and answer portion of today's call, please limit yourself to one question and one follow-up. Please use the raise hand button to join the question queue.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Before we jump into q and a,

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Zach will have some opening remarks. Zach?

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah. Thanks, Martin. Just to start off here, Q1 was a challenging but extremely successful quarter for the company. Despite numerous supply interruptions, including shutdowns at our Shanghai factory and nearby suppliers due to COVID, we've continued making progress and achieved our best ever vehicle deliveries. Last quarter, we demonstrated a series of new financial records including revenue, gross margins, operating margin and bottom line profitability.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: GAAP automotive gross margin reached thirty two point nine percent and for the first time exceeded thirty percent when excluding regulatory credits. Higher pricing continues to positively impact our financials as we make progress delivering cars in our growing backlog. Note that for most vehicles, our delivery wait times are quite long, thus cars delivered in Q1 generally carried pricing set in prior quarters and at levels lower than cars being ordered today. Our per unit vehicle cost increased as well. Inflation, raw material prices, expedites, and logistics costs continues to impact our cost structure.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Factory shutdowns also occurred with little to no notice, hence, we are unable to take action to plan those interruptions in a cost efficient manner. Additionally, we saw a slight mix shift towards more profitable vehicles including the Model y. We also recognized a onetime benefit of two hundred eighty eight million from credit revenue relating to a regulatory change in the US CAFE penalty without of which credit revenue would have declined compared to the same period last year. The energy business has continued to be impacted by macro conditions more severely than the vehicle business, Our storage products are in need of chip supply and new import processes have impact have impacted supply of certain components for our solar systems, which is reflected in our solar volume for the quarter. OpEx as a percentage of revenue continues to reduce driven by higher revenue, lower stock based comp expense and other items.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: As a result of our ongoing improvements in operating leverage, we achieved a record operating margin of over nineteen percent. Note that commissioning costs for our factories are in R and D as Berlin started production in late March and Austin in early April. These costs will be in automotive COGS going forward given these factories are now producing customer sellable cars. Our free cash flows have remained quite strong, yet we're impacted by working capital related to lower than planned production. Additionally, have reduced our debt excluding product financing to nearly zero.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Looking ahead in the immediate term, a few things to keep in mind for Q2. First, we've lost about a month of build volume out of our factory in Shanghai due to COVID related shutdowns. Production is resuming at limited levels and we're working to get back to full production as quickly as possible. This will impact total build and delivery volume in Q2. Second, as I've mentioned before, Austin and Berlin are just starting their ramps and thus those inefficiencies will start to flow through our gross margins in Q2.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Third, we do have higher ASPs in our backlog, which will help to offset some of these headwinds. We continue to drive towards further strengthening of our financials in the second half of the year and believe our fifty percent or above growth rate remains achievable for the year. I want to conclude by thanking the Tesla team, our suppliers and our new customers for a great first quarter.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Thank you very much. And Ilhan Nasa, opening remarks as well.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Sure. Some of my remarks will be redundant with Zacks, but it's maybe worth repeating. Q1 was once again a record quarter on many levels, reaching the highest deliveries, profit and an operating margin of nineteen percent. This was despite a lot of chip shortages, many logistics challenges and an overall difficult quarter. So I'd really like to congratulate the Tesla team on achieving record profitability and output despite many, many difficult headwinds and especially the Tesla China team and our Shanghai factory, they really had significant challenges due to the COVID shutdowns and nonetheless have been able to output a tremendous number of high quality vehicles.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: And we are already back up and running with the Shanghai factory. So as Zach said, we remain confident of a thirty percent growth in vehicle production in twenty twenty two versus twenty twenty one. I think we actually have a reasonable shot at a sixty percent increase over last year. So let's see, have production as people know with Gigabulin and Giga Texas in the past few months. So we're two fantastic factories with great teams and they are ramping rapidly.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Now with new factories, the initial ramp always looks small, but it grows exponentially. So but I have very high confidence in the teams of both factories and we expect to ramp those initially slowly but like I said growing exponentially with them achieving high volume by the end of this year. So see, we're also working on a new vehicle that I alluded to at the Giga Texas opening, which is a dedicated robotaxi that's highly optimized for autonomy, meaning it would not have steering wheel or pedals. And there are a number of other innovations around it that I think are quite exciting, but it's fundamentally optimized for it's trying to achieve the lowest fully considered cost per mile or cost per kilometer accounting everything. And so it's I think going to be a very powerful product where we aspire to reach volume production of that in twenty twenty four.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: So I think that really will be a massive driver of Tesla's growth. And we remain on track to reach volume production of the Cybertruck next year. Let's see, it's basically, once again, I'd like to thank Tesla employees for their hard work, but also I'd like to thank our suppliers who've really gone the extra mile. We have an amazing supplier group and I want to say heartfelt thanks to the suppliers that have really worked day and night to ensure that Telstra is able to keep the factories running. And we're really at at the early stage of our journey.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: We only crossed one million units in the the past twelve months recently and we are we aspire to head to twenty million units a year. So we're basically five percent along the way towards our goal. But we are growing very rapidly year over year and remain confident of exceeding fifty percent annual growth for the foreseeable future for basically several years, several of the next years. Mean, so yeah. And then there's, of course, Optimus, which I was surprised that people did not realize the magnitude of the Optimus robot program.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: This the importance of Optimus will become apparent in the coming years. Those who are insightful or listen carefully will understand that Optimus ultimately will be worth more than the car business, worth more than FSD. That's my firm belief. So and then of course, insurance is growing well. We expect to address the part shortages that limited our progress with batteries and solar.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: So So we expect batteries and solar to also grow well this year. And basically, the future is very exciting. I've never been more optimistic or excited about the Tesla's future than I am right now. Thank you.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Thank you very much. Let's go to first investor question. And the first investor question is Elon has historically provided FSD timelines with not optimal accuracy. We love its optimism for twenty twenty two release, But is there any data that I can share with investors to help them make their own conclusions on progress being made, interventions per mile driven, or any other data?

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Sure. Well, with respect to full self driving, of any technology development I've ever been involved in, I've I've never really seen more kind of false dawns or or where it seems like we're gonna break through, but but we don't as I've seen in full self driving. And ultimately, it comes down to is that to solve full self driving, you actually have to solve real world artificial intelligence, which is which nobody has solved. The whole road system is made for biological neural nets eyes. And so actually when you think about it, in order to solve full self driving, we have to solve neural nets and cameras to a degree of capability that is on par with and exceeds humans.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: And I I I think we will achieve that this year. The best way to reach your own assessment is to join the Tesla full self driving beta program. We have over a hundred thousand people right now enrolled in that program, and we expect to broaden that significantly this year. So that's that's my recommendation is is join the full self driving beta program and experience it for yourself and take note of the rate of improvement with every release. And we we put out a new release roughly every two weeks.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: So you'll see a little bit of two steps forward, one step back, but overall, the rate of improvement is incredibly quick. So that's my recommendation for reaching your own assessment is literally right.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Thank you. The second question is, how much of an impact will the production shutdown in Shanghai have in Q2? What is the timeline for localizing the Model three in Europe or will newer models be prioritized in Berlin?

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Well,

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: We did lose a lot of important days of production and there are sort of upstream supplier challenges where a lot of suppliers also have lost many days of production. But Tesla Shanghai Giga Shanghai is going back with a vengeance. So I think notwithstanding new issues that arise, think we will see a record output per week from Kyrgyz Shanghai this quarter, albeit we are missing a couple of weeks. So that means that most likely vehicle production in Q2 will be similar to Q1, maybe slightly lower, but it's also possible we may pull a ramp out the hat and and be slightly higher, but it's a bit, call it, roughly on par. But then but then q three and q four will be substantially higher.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: So it it, you know, it it seems likely that we'll be able to produce over one and a half million cars this year. It's my That's that's my best guess. And then model three, it's important for new factories to be focused on and have the least amount of complexity and variation, which is why Gigabull and Giga Texas are focused on the Model Y. It's it's from the point which you have a factory complete and you're making a small number of units to the point where it's producing high quality vehicles in volume is, you know, sort of nine to twelve months from start of production. So now hopefully we're we're getting better at that ramp, so maybe it's a little less.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: But to get to sort of the five thousand a week level is typically taking us around twelve months from starter production.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Thank you. The next question is how much raw material exposure do you have measured roughly in percentage of cost of goods sold, for example, in a given quarter versus one to two years out, both direct and indirect? Separately, how do you think about price increases versus prioritizing higher mix vehicles going forward? Actually, price increase front, I

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: should mention that it may seem like maybe we're being unreasonable about increasing the prices of our vehicles given that we had record profitability this quarter. But the waitlist for our vehicles is quite long. And some of the vehicles that people will order, the waitlist extends into next year. So our prices of vehicles ordered now are really anticipating supplier and logistics cost growth that we're aware of and believe will happen over the next six to twelve months. So that's why we have the price increases today because the car ordered today will arrive in some cases a year from now.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: We have a very long wait list and we're obviously not demand limited, we are production limited by very much production limited.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Raw material exposure?

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah, just to add to what Ioann is saying, you know, there's there's different ways to calculate raw material exposure. I mean, I think a simple way we estimate we're around ten to fifteen percent of our cost structure exposed to raw materials. And,

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: you know, just

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: just to clarify a couple of things on that. So we've we've been experiencing increases in costs in general, but also raw materials for a number of quarters now. That pace picked up in q q one, so last quarter. And what we're seeing for q two is slightly higher than that as well. And, you know, as indices move, it doesn't impact us immediately or directly.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: In some cases, we have contracts with suppliers, but then as those contracts expire, we have to renegotiate them so that there can be a lag. In some cases, our contracts do directly reflect movement in commodity prices or raw material prices, but, you know, the timing in which that that that Tesla pays for that has a lag associated with it as well based on the contract. And so to Elon's point, what we're trying to do here because it's quite an unprecedented situation of raw material movement and all of these various lags and uncertainty around renegotiating contracts is we're trying to anticipate where things will go and make sure that the pricing that we have put in place at the time that those raw material cost increases hit us, that they align and that the company can remain financially healthy in various scenarios as we look out over the next four quarters.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Okay. Thank you very much. The next question is, why does Tesla continue to fight dealership laws on a state by state basis versus taking it federal? Separately, why isn't Tesla using a eight hundred volt architecture in its vehicles? What are the advantages or disadvantages?

They look like, you know, it it really just think of like just macro tonnage. speaker: Martin Viecha
text: So right now we think mining and refining lithium is, it appears to be a limiting factor and it certainly is responsible for quite a bit of cost growth in the cells. It's the single biggest cost growth item right now, so they're a percentage basis. Although just for those who who don't totally know this, the actual content of lithium in the lithium ion cell is is maybe around two or three percent of the cell.

So that's the the nickel or the iron phosphate. And I think we've got we don't have enough time on this call to really go through all those details, but we are thinking about these things and we think we'll have some exciting announcements in the months to come.

speaker: Martin Viecha

So we're looking at the beginning and end of life needs here.

We regrind any plastic that goes out. And so we're really concerned about raw materials, not just, like, mining them and consuming them, but when we get them in the door, using all hundred percent of them.

So that gives us the ability to be pretty deliberate in the forty six eighty ramp where we can maximize learning step by step, take engineering downtime to upgrade key pieces of equipment and modify the structural pack design to improve reliability all while achieving what you just said. So

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Thank you very much. Let's go to analyst questions now. The first question comes from Dan Levi from CSFP. Please go ahead and unmute yourself.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Sure. I mean, at a high level, cars produced in Shanghai do carry a lower cost structure than cars produced in Fremont. And so as our mix of cars shift towards Shanghai, the average cost is positively impacted by that. We're also seeing some progress in manufacturing efficiencies in Fremont, particularly on the S and X side as volume increases improves there. Expedites has been a huge story for the company.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Q four, we had massive amounts of expedites. Q one was still quite large, but we did make progress bringing that down some.

And our supply chain team, in particular, production planning portion of supply team supply chain. We we often get very little notice when there's part shortages coming, and it's kind of a scramble couple days before that part is supposed to arrive to figure out how to get it here. And so the amount of herculean effort that goes in to produce a quarter like q one, even the quarters before that is is absolutely immense.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: And so

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: I mean, it's like the same military, you know, it's like amateurs talk about tactics, professionals talk about logistics when it comes to war. Yeah.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: So there were some inherent cost improvements as I mentioned, but there's also offsets that we've talked about previously in raw materials, commodities. Outbound logistics continues to remain a challenge despite a ton of efforts to increase capacity there and bring those costs down.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Sandeep, follow-up. Sorry, go ahead.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yes, thank you. Second question, you know, one of the initial goals of Model three way back when was to have an EV that was affordable for a wide portion of the market. And, you know, we know prices are are much higher now just given the supply constraints. Prices are are higher for for all other automakers. We know that there's inflation that you're battling through, and some of that needs to be passed through to the to price the vehicles.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: And you're gonna be supply constrained for the foreseeable future, so it's sort of a moot point. But given the the goal long term of making EVs more widely available to the masses over time, how how do you look at the progression of prices over time?

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: We we absolutely want to make EVs as affordable as possible. It's been very difficult with the I mean, I think inflation is at like a forty or fifty year high, and I think the the official numbers actually understate the true magnitude of inflation. So and and that inflation appears to be likely to continue for at least the remainder of this year is is what, you know, when we're talking to suppliers, suppliers are under severe cost pressure. So, in some cases, we're seeing suppliers request twenty, thirty twenty to thirty percent cost increases for parts from last year to the end of this, you know, to the end of this year. So it's there's there's a lot of cost pressure there.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: That's that's why we raised our prices because we and it I think when things with the sun said was with respect to inflation, but, you know, it's high, then we and we've got orders that go out a year or more in some cases, then we have to anticipate those cost increases. But I think especially with the robotaxi and autonomy, I think we will end up providing consumers with by far the lowest cost per mile of transport that they've ever experienced.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah. I mean, you

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: know, with the road tax, like, maybe five to ten times lower cost per mile, it's really quite substantial. They're more accessible to everybody.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: I mean, it okay. On looking at some of our projections, it it would appear that a robo taxi ride will cost less than a bus ticket, a subsidized bus ticket or or subsidized subway ticket.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Thank you very much. Let's go to the next question from Rod Lache from Wolfe Research.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Hi, everybody. I'm trying to just parse out your comments about the inflation and constrained supply and battery feedstocks and the initiatives that you are working on internally to secure these materials. It it sounds like, you're optimistic about Tesla's ability to solve this for Tesla. Do you but do you see this as as a constraint on EV adoption more broadly?

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah. Absolutely. You know, what's keeping our cost down, at least in the short term, is that we have long term contracts with suppliers, but those long term contracts will obviously run out and then we'll start to see potentially significant cost increases. The macros sort of looking at the world as a whole and saying, okay. What does it take for Earth to transition to sustainable energy faster?

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: It's it's fundamentally the fundamental limiting factor is the output of the cell, the basic cell output. What rate can lithium ion cells increase the gigawatt hours per year? That is the fundamental limiting factor. So in order for and that will move as fast as the slowest least lucky element of the whole supply chain. Currently, see that as being a challenge with lithium.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: And it's not that to be clear, it's not that there's a shortage of lithium ore in the world. Lithium is present almost everywhere. It's a very common element. However, you you still need to to, you know, dig up the ore, dig up basically some logamine or whatever the the the clay with the lithium, and and then you need to go through a whole series of refinement steps. And that's a lot of industrial equipment that's needed to refine lithium or to lithium that can be used as lithium hydroxide or lithium carbonate in the battery cell.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: So we think we're going to need to help the industry on this front. But the industry is very, very fast and I'd certainly encourage entrepreneurs out there who are looking for opportunities to get into the lithium business. Lithium margins right now are practically software margins. Mean, the I think of it's something that this doesn't mean, Zach, correct me if I'm wrong, but I think we're seeing cases where the spot lithium price is ten times higher than the cost of extraction. So not like we're talking nineteen percent margins here.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Can more people please get into the lithium business? Do you like minting money? Well, the lithium business is for you.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Interesting. So I guess we'll stay tuned to see what happens from that. My second question is it's impressive to see just a modest increase in cost vehicle, cost of goods sold per vehicle, given what we've seen in terms of commodities, actually. And from here, have a lot of savings, opportunities with four thousand six hundred eighty cells and the cell manufacturing changes, the anode chemistry, structural packs, gigacastings. Are you suggesting that even those may not be sufficient to offset the inflation that you're seeing and that you're going to need additional pricing as well in addition to those specific initiatives that you've called out?

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: We hope we don't need to increase the pricing further. The current pricing is anticipating what we think is the probable growth in costs. And if that growth in cost does not materialize, we actually may slightly reduce prices. So PureCloud currently anticipate making significant price increases, but obviously we don't control the macroeconomic environment. If governments keep printing vast amounts of money and, you know, and and if if there's not if they're not significant increases in lithium extraction and refinements and and the other raw materials such that everyone's competing for a limited amount of raw materials, then obviously that that will drive prices to to high levels.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: So if if you you if you have a crystal ball that can tell us what the future is gonna be like, we'll adjust accordingly, but the current prices are what what we the current prices are for a vehicle delivered in the future, like, six to twelve months from now. So this is our best guess.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: But I think if you zoom out, right, like, as you said, our mission is to accelerate the transition to sustainable energy. So we are working with our existing suppliers and others to figure out how to grow all of these raw materials as quickly as possible to not slow down the transition. Yeah. And, you know, whether that means we have to get directly involved in some cases or not comes down to the counterparty and their willingness to expand at the rate we think they should be able to expand. And that that's similar to what we've done with everything else.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Like, we built a Gigafactory in Reno because it needed to be done.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: And so, like, we will do what needs to be done to not slow down the transition, and affordability is a goal. Because if it's unaffordable, it it's gonna retard the growth of of what is inherently a good thing. So we we can't have that as an outcome.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Thank you. The next question comes from Pierre Ferragu from New Street Research.

text: Hi. Can you hear me? Can you hear me well? Yes. Great.

So, you know, we're see what five hundred billion dollars buys you in, you know, in a decade, but it might be a lot less. So I I don't know if we'll that seems like a lot of cash. I don't know.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: We'll try to do something useful with it. I mean, drag your I don't know. So I realize that problem. That's for sure.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Thank you very much. The next question comes from Alex Potter from Piper Sandler. Alex, can you hear us?

text: Yes. Hi, Martin, can you hear me?

text: Yes.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Okay, great. So first question I had was the extent to which other plants outside of China are insulated from any further upstream supply bottlenecks that we may have in China. Obviously, if this COVID lockdown thing gets out of hand, clearly, that's going to continue impacting Shanghai. But is there a point at which it could actually also impact other facilities?

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yes, if it were to continue, but there are some parts vessels in China that apply worldwide and that would be that would impact production elsewhere. But all indications are that are King of Shanghai is back in production at fairly high levels already and so are our suppliers. So we don't think this is going to be a big deal.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Okay. Thanks. Second question. Obviously, the higher profitability you guys have been able to experience over the last couple

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: of quarters, a lot

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: of that

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: is reflecting sort of real improvements. Another part of it is because we're no longer paying you, Ivan, as much as we were. So I'm wondering the extent to which you and the Board are in the process of contemplating another one of these long term compensation packages, which in

text: the past have seemed to work out quite well.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: There are no discussions currently underway for incremental competition for me.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Thank you. The next question comes from Colin Langham from Wells Fargo.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Great. Can you guys hear me? Yes.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yes. Perfect. Just a follow-up,

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: sorry to keep going on the raw material issue on the battery side, but obviously, it seems pretty important. How quickly can raw material supply be built? Because my understanding, it takes many years to build that out. So are we just sort of facing when do you think we see a lithium shortage or a nickel shortage? And is there even enough time to build that sort of mining capacity in place?

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: And then related, how quickly can you switch to like LFP you know, for for the nickel issue?

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah. I mean, I I'll take the LFP question. Like, you know, it says so in our letter, but, like, half of our products were LFP last quarter, which shows how quickly we were able to respond to well, honestly, it wasn't because of a raw material shortage, but just because it seemed like the right thing to do, we could change our cathode chemistry. And there's more to be done on the cathode side, and we are actively pursuing it to to give us substitution flexibility in response to market conditions between the the other cathode cathodes that are out there that can be competitive in our vehicles of which there are are many options. So, you know, we we we I guess, what I would say is, specifically on the cathode side, like, flexibility is the is the way we're going to achieve this, and not all of the materials that go into cathodes are actually, first of all, to secure, like, through mining or refining.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: And and second of all, in in many cases, they're, like, very plentiful already, like, scale. And, you know, if all of the batteries in the world use those cathodes, it's less than a one percent increase in total annual output. So that's that's the that's the cathode side. You know, I think Elon already spent a lot of time talking about lithium. It really depends on the resource.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Some resources, like just getting rocks out of the ground, you know, expanding the amount of rocks that you're getting out of the ground is, you know, maybe a little bit of paperwork and some additional, sort of the blasting and and and trucking operations. The refining is is is maybe where there's, you know, it's a little bit more chunky to to bring it online, but also the refining doesn't it's not like an oil refinery. It's a much much smaller operation to refine, lithium out of spodumene or or or liquid, like a brine or or a salt salt pond evaporation. So, you know, you're talking about a timescale of one to two years, and it's not like we haven't been talking, to all of the lithium suppliers out there for many years. They have a lot of projects already in the pipeline to come online this year and next.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Some of what's going on in the lithium market this year doesn't actually have truth to bear to the, like, fundamentals of supply and demand, which is also a little frustrating. But but but, yeah, if we look past this year or next year and into two thousand thirty when we need fifteen to twenty terawatt hours of this stuff to, you know, get on the growth trajectory stay on the growth trajectory we're on, we need we need everybody to do more in the lithium space than they currently are. I don't know if that answers the question.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah. Fantastic. Thank you very much. So let's go to the last question from Mark Delaney from Goldman Sachs.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yes. Good afternoon and thank you very much for taking the question. I was hoping you could comment on your latest thoughts about potentially opening up the charging network in the U. S. To non Tesla owners.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Certainly, really important to have a good experience for Tesla owners terms of wait times and charging stalls. But if if Tesla's able to have enough capacity, you know, it could be a really good way to bring other vehicle owners into the Tesla network, perhaps help Tesla to sustain its network benefits and and maybe make more people likely to buy Tesla vehicles in the future.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah. As as Elon has said and as we've publicly committed, yeah, we we do plan to to provide third party vehicle access in all over the world, not just in Europe where our original pilot was. And we are working on solutions in North America, which is a little bit more problematic with our connector being different than others. But we are moving in that direction.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: I don't if you want

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: to add.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah. I think that's there's not even more to be said on that part. Yeah. We wanna do the right things with respect to the whole the whole system. Mhmm.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: And and we're going faster on adding chargers. Absolutely. Like, with the growth of the cars that we're producing and then anticipating what Drew is discussing, overall charger capacity is really important. And so the the pace of our investments in supercharging has accelerated. Absolutely.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Okay. That's helpful. And, for my second question, could you share any more details on Tesla insurance in particular as you're rolling it out in more states? You know, are there any metrics you can share on what take rates have been like, and how do profitability margins on the insurance offering compared to

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: the corporate average? Thank you.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Okay. So

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: we just launched Tesla Insurance for real time insurance in Virginia, Colorado, and Oregon earlier this week. Maybe one step that I'll share is that Texas is our longest standing real time insurance market. Based on the information that we have, you know, Tesla is the second largest insurer of Teslas in the state of Texas. And possibly by the end of this quarter, maybe early next quarter, we'll be the largest insurer of Teslas. And so, you know, the customer reception to this has been quite positive.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: And, I was reading social media on Monday after we launched in the three new states. You know, a lot of folks were reporting their stories of saving quite substantial amounts of money relative to their previous insurance. And so we're quite encouraged by that, and we're working as quickly as we can to get to eighty percent of customers having access to a Tesla insurance product by the end of this year, in the United States, you know, at which point we'll pivot our attention to expansion outside of the US. The other thing I'll say on insurance is with these three new states, the the model is different because we are now the underwriter, and we are also not holding the risk. And so with those states, we are a fully vertically integrated provider of insurance from systems and financials.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: With with respect to the financials of the program, it's still very early. And so, you know, as the program gets more scale, happy to share more information on that.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: And one one side note is that we are seeing that the having real time feedback for driving habits is actually resulting in Tesla owners driving the cars in a safer way. So, you know, because they can see the they get real time feedback on, okay. This is this is affecting my insurance rate or it isn't. And and so when people see it consider a real time score and realize that if I if I make the polling changes in my driving habits, then I pay less in insurance, then they have a, you know, a very like, a real time feedback loop for driving for safer driving and an incentive to do so. So it is actually what we're seeing is it is causing people to drive their cars in a safer manner, which is still also not good.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: It's safer on average, what we see in the data to Elan's point, and premiums are lower. We see that in the take rate data with extremely high retention, for customers who experience the product. Product. And and I think I've talked about this

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: in the past, but this has become a

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: real passion program for us Yeah. You know, for these benefits. It's it's bigger than just the economics. We're trying to do a good thing here, for our customers, save save people money, and make the roads a little bit safer.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah. I think it improves just overall macroeconomic efficiency. It's also a feedback loop for for Tesla because we see if if there is, you know, a crash, large or small, like, we we we sort of see exactly what that cost. And and and now we're able to think about how can we change the design of the car or the software in order to minimize the probability of that, you know, accident. These most accidents accidents are minor, but how do we have those accidents occur less frequently, and and how do we make the repair associated with an accident that accident super fast?

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Like, aspirationally, it'd be, like, same day repair from for a collision, you know, which is just night and day difference compared to sometimes having to wait for a month while insurance claims are settled and figured out and because because Tesla's also doing collision repair.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: But, yeah, the feedback loop is instant. Yeah. Right? So, I mean, we do claims management in house, and so we received the notification that there's an accident. We work to prepare the estimate, and and we can, you know, with the support of our customers, use our collision centers to do the repair.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: And so it's, you know, full end to end visibility and all of that to Elon's point. We can then identify areas of cost and efficiency, feed those back to engineering teams or elsewhere, software teams, actually improve the product, which lowers the cost of turns, improves reliability of the product. So it's a full full circle.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Yeah. And it's a like, basically, the customer experience is just vastly better because if if there's an accident, it it there's no argument. It's it's we we we repair it immediately. And this is as compared to arguing with an insurance company and then a claims adjuster and then a collision repair center. And this could be a nightmare, basically.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: So we wanna try to to turn a nightmare into agreeing with Tesla Insurance.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Fantastic. Thank you very much. Unfortunately, that's all the time we have for this quarter. So thank you very much for all your great questions, and we'll speak to you again in three months.
